metadata.titleEn: The observation data of permafrost active layer depth along the Qinghai-Tibet Highway (2004-2009)
metadata.description:
This data set contains observational data of permafrost active layer depth and surface landscape from six locations along the Qinghai-Tibet Highway from 2004 to 2009. 
Data source: the Local Investigation of Permafrost on the Tibetan Plateau funded by the Specialized Program of Basic Science and Technology. The observation method is the soil temperature method, which is to observe the interannual variation of the active layer depth in permafrost regions by laying out an active layer temperature probe. The data are calculated and reorganized at last.

background: Permafrost, defined as ground that remains at or below 0 °C for at least 2 consecutive years (Dobinski, 2011), underlies more than 20 % of the exposed land area in the Northern Hemisphere (Obu et al., 2019) and constitutes an essential component of the Earth system. The Qinghai–Tibet Plateau (QTP), also known as the Earth’s third pole, contains the largest mid- to low-latitude permafrost area in the world. Due to the complex topography and unique plateau climate, permafrost over the QTP is generally of low thermal stability and strongly influenced by complex local factors, such as terrain, vegetation cover, soil properties, and hydrological conditions, which differentiate it from high-latitude permafrost around the Arctic and make it more sensitive to global climate change (Li et al., 2008; Yang et al., 2019; Zhao et al., 2020). In the context of global warming, significant permafrost degradation is occurring on the QTP and has strongly affected hydrological processes (Li et al., 2020), carbon cycling (Mu et al., 2020), and heat exchange processes (Zhao et al., 2020). In addition, hazards related to permafrost degradation threaten construction and infrastructure on the QTP (Wang et al., 2020). Many researchers have studied the complex responses and feedback of permafrost to climate change (Yang et al., 2019), while land surface model-based spatial modeling of permafrost has become an important approach (Ji et al., 2022). Using land surface models, many spatial modeling studies have attempted to project future changes in permafrost (Chang et al., 2018; Debolskiy et al., 2020; Yin et al., 2021), assess the permafrost status under climate change (Koven et al., 2013; Burke et al., 2020), diagnose the contributors to regional permafrost degradation (Zhang et al., 2021a, b; Mekonnen et al., 2021), and project potential feedbacks on the climate system due to permafrost degradation (Zhang et al., 2020; Andresen et al., 2020; Yokohata et al., 2020; Wang et al., 2021). However, evaluating the spatial simulations for the QTP can be challenging due to the limited availability of ground observations, which may not be sufficient to serve as references across the vast spatial modeling domain.
research objective: Based on these criteria, this study aims to produce a permafrost distribution map over the QTP in 2010 through an effective permafrost mapping approach that considers the effects of local factors and utilizes observational data, including remote sensing data and survey-based subregion permafrost maps, as optimization targets and constraints. Our objective is to provide a new reference map for 2010 for permafrost studies on the QTP and to provide a benchmark map for transient simulations of QTP permafrost under climate change.
challenges: Uncertainties associated with mapping approaches also negatively impact the accuracy of existing permafrost maps. Common statistical learning methods for permafrost mapping (Wang et al., 2019c; Ni et al., 2021) heavily rely on in situ observations as a training dataset. Therefore, they are often compromised when ground observations are unevenly distributed and have different observation periods, as is the case for the QTP. The lack of accurate soil properties, fine-tuned parameterization schemes, and high-resolution forcing data on the QTP severely challenged the applications of land surface models in mapping permafrost (Wu et al., 2018). These physically explicit models were often calibrated and validated at a point scale, leading to unpredictable uncertainties when extended to a large region with more variability and, thus, more complex conditions (Qin et al., 2017; Wu et al., 2018).
methods: In this study, we created a new permafrost distribution map for the QTP in 2010 using a novel permafrost mapping approach with satellite-derived ground surface thawing and freezing indices as inputs and survey-based subregion permafrost maps as constraints. This approach accounted for the effects of local factors by incorporating (into the model) an empirical soil parameter whose values were optimally estimated through spatial clustering and parameter optimization constrained by survey-based subregion permafrost maps, and the approach was also improved to reduce parametric equifinality.
dataset: The dataset is available from the repository hosted on Figshare (Cao et al., 2022): https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.19642362.
findings: This new map showed a total permafrost area of about 1.086 ×106 km2 (41.2 % of the QTP area) and seasonally frozen ground of about 1.447 ×106 km2 (54.9 %) in 2010, excluding glaciers and lakes. Validations using survey-based subregion permafrost maps (κ=0.74) and borehole records (overall accuracy=0.85 and κ=0.43) showed a higher accuracy of this map compared with two other recent maps. Inspection of regions with obvious distinctions between the maps affirms that the permafrost distribution on this map is more realistic than that on the Zou et al. (2017) map. Given the demonstrated excellent accuracy, this map can serve as a benchmark map for constraining/validating land surface simulations on the QTP and as a historical reference for projecting future permafrost changes on the QTP in the context of global warming.

Definition.Question: What does 'soil temperature method' mean in the context of data collection for permafrost studies?
Definition.Answer: The 'soil temperature method' refers to a data collection technique where soil temperature is measured using temperature probes to observe changes in the active layer thickness of permafrost regions over time.

Definition.Question: What does 'land surface model-based spatial modeling' mean in the context of permafrost research?
Definition.Answer: 'Land surface model-based spatial modeling' is a research approach that uses models to simulate the spatial distribution and future changes of permafrost by incorporating local factors such as terrain, vegetation, and soil properties, along with climate data.

Definition.Question: What does 'empirical soil parameter' imply in the context of permafrost mapping approaches?
Definition.Answer: An 'empirical soil parameter' in permafrost mapping refers to a model variable whose values are optimally estimated based on empirical data, such as survey-based maps, to account for local influences and improve the accuracy of permafrost distribution models.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when mapping permafrost using survey-based subregion maps compared to in situ observations?
Comparison.Answer: Mapping permafrost using survey-based subregion maps involves challenges related to the accuracy of existing maps and the need for optimization targets and constraints. On the other hand, in situ observations face issues with uneven distribution and varying observation periods, which affect the training datasets for statistical learning methods.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges can be inferred from the lack of evenly distributed in situ observations when collecting data on permafrost regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The uneven distribution of in situ observations compromises the accuracy of statistical learning methods used for permafrost mapping. It leads to uncertainties when these observations have different periods, making it challenging to serve as reliable references across extensive spatial modeling domains.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of satellite-derived indices and subregion permafrost maps enhance the understanding of local factors affecting permafrost distribution?
Interpretation.Answer: By incorporating satellite-derived thawing and freezing indices and using subregion permafrost maps as constraints, researchers can better account for local factors, such as soil properties and terrain, which improve the modeling accuracy and reduce parametric equifinality in permafrost distribution maps.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes uncertainties associated with permafrost mapping approaches in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Uncertainties in permafrost mapping approaches are often caused by the reliance on unevenly distributed in situ observations, different observation periods, lack of accurate soil properties, fine-tuned parameterization schemes, and high-resolution forcing data, which challenge the application of land surface models over the complex conditions of the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to evaluate spatial simulations of permafrost on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Evaluating spatial simulations of permafrost on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau is challenging due to the limited availability of ground observations, which may not be sufficient to serve as references across the vast spatial modeling domain.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to the unique sensitivity of permafrost on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau to global climate change?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The unique sensitivity of permafrost on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau to global climate change is influenced by complex local factors such as terrain, vegetation cover, soil properties, and hydrological conditions, making it more sensitive compared to high-latitude permafrost around the Arctic.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on permafrost mapping accuracy when using satellite-derived indices as inputs compared to traditional ground-based observations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using satellite-derived ground surface thawing and freezing indices as inputs allows for a more comprehensive approach to mapping permafrost over large regions like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. This method can provide higher accuracy by incorporating broad-scale data, reducing reliance on unevenly distributed ground-based observations. However, it still requires validation against survey-based subregion permafrost maps and borehole records to ensure its effectiveness.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of limited ground observations on the development of spatial models for permafrost assessment?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Limited ground observations can challenge the accuracy of spatial models for permafrost assessment, as they often serve as critical references for model calibration and validation. This limitation can lead to increased uncertainties in mapping outcomes, especially across vast and diverse regions like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. Therefore, enhancing observation networks or using alternative data sources like remote sensing can be crucial for improving model reliability.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective behind collecting observational data on permafrost thawing and freezing indices using satellite-derived information for permafrost mapping?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to create an accurate permafrost distribution map for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau that considers local factors and utilizes observational data, including remote sensing data, to optimize and constrain the mapping approach.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to address the challenges associated with the uneven distribution and varying periods of in situ observations in permafrost mapping?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Addressing these challenges is crucial because they compromise the accuracy of permafrost maps, particularly when using statistical learning methods that heavily rely on in situ observations as a training dataset. This is especially important for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, where ground observations are sparse and unevenly distributed.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of producing a new reference permafrost map for 2010 for the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals are to provide a benchmark map for transient simulations of permafrost under climate change and offer a new reference for permafrost studies on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, thereby aiding in validating and constraining land surface simulations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in using soil temperature methods to measure permafrost active layer thickness along the Qinghai–Tibet Highway?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps involve setting up active layer temperature probes to monitor the interannual variations in permafrost active layer thickness. The data is then calculated and compiled for analysis.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can remote sensing data and survey-based subregion maps be integrated to optimize permafrost mapping on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Remote sensing data and survey-based subregion maps can be integrated in a permafrost mapping approach by using satellite-derived thawing and freezing indices as inputs and utilizing survey-based maps as constraints. This involves spatial clustering and parameter optimization techniques to account for local factors and reduce parametric equifinality.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What challenges exist in using ground observations as a training dataset for permafrost mapping on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau, and how can these be addressed?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges include uneven distribution of ground observations and varying observation periods, which can be addressed by improving soil property accuracy, refining parameterization schemes, and obtaining high-resolution forcing data to support land surface models.

Enablement.Question: What technological innovations have enabled the accurate observation of permafrost activity layer thickness over the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The use of soil temperature measurement techniques, involving the installation of active layer temperature probes, has enabled the accurate observation of permafrost activity layer thickness in this region.

Enablement.Question: How do ground observations and remote sensing data integration facilitate the development of high-accuracy permafrost distribution maps?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of ground observations with remote sensing data allows for the optimization and constraint of permafrost mapping approaches, improving accuracy by considering local factors and using empirical soil parameters estimated through spatial clustering and parameter optimization.

Enablement.Question: What are the challenges associated with using statistical learning methods for permafrost mapping in areas with unevenly distributed ground observations?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include reliance on in situ observations that are unevenly distributed and have varying observation periods, leading to compromised accuracy. The lack of accurate soil properties, parameterization schemes, and high-resolution forcing data further complicates the use of statistical learning methods.

Expectation.Question: Why might existing permafrost maps fail to serve as reliable benchmarks for land surface modeling on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Existing maps may not be reliable benchmarks due to uncertainties associated with mapping approaches, which heavily rely on in situ observations that are unevenly distributed and have varying observation periods, leading to compromised accuracy in large and variable regions like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential limitations of relying on soil temperature methods for observing active layer thickness in permafrost regions, and how might these impact the data's accuracy?
Judgmental.Answer: The soil temperature method, while useful for observing active layer thickness, can face limitations such as spatial variability in soil properties, which may lead to inaccuracies in temperature data interpretation. Additionally, the uneven distribution of measurement sites along the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau could result in data gaps, impacting the overall accuracy of permafrost observations and subsequent modeling efforts.

Assertion.Answer: The data collection methods involve using soil temperature probes to measure the active layer thickness and observing surface landscapes. These methods allow for monitoring interannual changes in permafrost regions, which is crucial for accurate measurements.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges associated with mapping permafrost distribution in regions with complex terrain like the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include uncertainties in mapping approaches due to uneven distribution of ground observations, differing observation periods, lack of accurate soil properties, and the need for high-resolution forcing data. This complexity makes it difficult to apply land surface models effectively.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how datasets on permafrost distribution are validated for accuracy in such vast and variable terrains.
Assertion.Answer: Datasets are validated using survey-based subregion permafrost maps and borehole records, which provide a benchmark for comparison. The new permafrost distribution map for example, showed higher accuracy when validated against these references.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges associated with data collection for permafrost mapping on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau and suggest potential methods to overcome these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in data collection for permafrost mapping on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau include the uneven distribution of in situ observations and differing observation periods, which affect the reliability of statistical learning methods. Additionally, there is a lack of accurate soil properties, high-resolution forcing data, and fine-tuned parameterization schemes. To overcome these challenges, incorporating satellite-derived ground surface thawing and freezing indices, optimizing empirical soil parameters using spatial clustering, and using survey-based subregion permafrost maps as constraints can be potential methods.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline a potential data collection method that could improve the accuracy of permafrost distribution maps on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: A potential data collection method to improve the accuracy of permafrost distribution maps on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau could involve using satellite-derived ground surface thawing and freezing indices as inputs, combined with an empirical soil parameter optimized through spatial clustering and survey-based subregion permafrost maps. This approach can account for local factors and reduce parametric equifinality, leading to more accurate permafrost mapping.
